bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Direccion de Salubridad, May 18, 1921

div1.p: Hanson requests an increase of funds. He discusses his dealings with local authorities and steamship companies.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Direccion de Salubridad, May 18, 1921
div1.opener:
Chiclayo May 18, 1921.
Direccion de Salubridad,
Lima, Peru.
Sirs:
div1.p:
Some time ago I wrote you about certain necessary increases in the salaries
of the Physicians who are lending their services to the Sanitary Campaign for
yellow fever. In reply I have received your telegram in regard to Drs. Tapia
of Libertad and Dies Canseco of Lambayeque, in which you state that you have
no request from me in regard to the others. I have also received, today, copy
of the Resolution in regard to the matter.

In regard to Dr. Cavassa of Guadelupe I understand that he has been
receiving Lp 10.0.00 per month for his work in connection with the bubonic
plague in his section. During this campaign he will have a considerable amount
of work in Guadelupe and Pueblo Nuevo and the small places in the immediate
surrounding territory which will interfere considerably with his private prac-
tice and I there fore recommend that he be given an additional allowance of
Lp 20.0.000 for the duration of this campaign. He is a good physician and a
conscientious enthusiastic worker and will be of a great deal of help to us.
This pay should be made effective from the first of April, which corresponds
to the time he has been working with the Commission. He will then be assigned
all the northern section and will relieve Dr. Ricardo Mendoza for other and
more important investigations in the valley which leads up to Chelete.

Dr. Ricardo Mendoza and his assistants have done excellent work in
the Province of Pacasmayo. In my inspections there I personally did not finds
any pupae, and the larvae which I found were very young. From the data on hand
I think it is safe to say that ther work there has prevented the appearance
of the fever in epidemic form, and has placed the province in such a condition
that an epidemic can not occur there this year.

Dr. Mendoza asked for increase in pay, and I personally think that he
has done such good work that it ought to be recognized by an increase if such a
thing is possible. I think that Lp 80.0.00 would be justifiable as salary for
him.

While in Pacasmayo he told me that he had not been paid for ten days
in January. He has handed me the receipts which he prapered for the Tesorero
Fiscal here in Chiclayo, but it was not paid. He was on duty all the time from
the date of his resolution of nomination and ought to be paid accordingly.

As you have noticed I included him in the budget for the International
Health Board, but he states that he thinks the Government ought to furnish some
of the principal men of the campaign, and in this I agree with him. I think the
Government should pay both his salary and expenses.

In regard to Dr. Enrique Caballero I have engaged him at the rate of
Lp 60.0.00 and expenses, for a special mission of investigation, to make sure
that the fever is not going to get away from us again. He is a man who has the
confidence of both Dr. Carter and myself and is a very valuable aquisition to
the Sanitary Campaign. He is engaged for the duration of the anti-yellow fever
campaign. I have already notified you about this matter, and should very much
appreciate receiving your approval. Can you take him on the account of the
Government or will I be obliged to take him on the International Health
Board account?

I have just received word that Corrigan and Pickett are sailing on
the first boat leaving Balboa after the date of the 15th of this month. This
I presume has been arranged directly with the International Health Board by
Dr. Carter, and is not a contract of mine.

I also wish to invite your attention to the fact that from the time
of my arrival up to date I have only received Lp 1000.0.00 for campaign expenses
and the Tesorero Fiscal says that he has received no more funds for the campaign.
Is it not possible to arrange a regular monthly allowance, with instructions
3. Salubridad, May 18, 1921.
that this amount must not be used for any other purpose? If I am notified of
each delivery of funds to the Tesorero Fiscal I can collect it and deposit it
in the Banco de Peru y Londres, where we carry the Government account, and show
the use of it in each monthly statement.

The epidemic here is falling off, but we are still having a few
scattered cases. This is due to the fact that the people do not take any pains
with their water containers. The Prefecto here is very indifferent in the matter
and it is very difficult to get any moral support from the authorities. This is
very different in the Province of Pacasmayo where the Sub-Prefecto has been
giving a most praiseworthy assistance, and has personally taken the trouble to
make sure that Dr. Mendozas orders have been complied with. Where fines have
been imposed for neglect the Sub-Prefecto has insisted that the finse be made
effective. This has had a most excellent moral effect. If we could get the same
kind of effect are support from the authorities here our dificulties would be
diminished by more than one-half.

I believe the Prefecto of Libertad will give us all necessary assis-
tance, for that is what he told me.

The measures which the steamship companies have taken unjustifiably is
to a large extent responsible for a lot of the propaganda which has arisen against
the campaign. It ought to be explained to them that they ought to touch those
ports for mail and cargo, and passengers in accordance with the quarantine regu-
lations. In regard to the latter I see no object in preventing passenger traffic
between the points of Pimentel and Salavarry, these and all intermediate ports
will be under the same sanitary conditions from now on till the end of the campaign.

I have sent you several reports and letters but have received no acknowl-
edgement of the receipt of any of them. Kindly let me know if they have been re-
ceived, also pointing out any objectionable features.
div1.closer:
Respectfully yours, Henry Hanson, M.D.,
Director of Sanitary Campaign.
